name: wheat grain production | wheat grain | Cutoff, U
description:
ecoQuery: https://ecoquery.ecoinvent.org/3.10/cutoff/dataset/19819/documentation

This dataset represents the production of 1 kg of wheat grain (wet mass) in South Africa.The dataset is representative of the 2016-2017 growing season, which produced 1.92 million tonnes at an overall yield of 3.8 tonnes/ha. The datasets is modelled with 62% of wheat grown under dryland conditions and 38% is irrigated, with the percentage of wheat grown under dryland conditons and that grown under irrigated conditions is extrapolated from the 2006 growing season (the latest for which this information is available) and average yields of 3 tonnes/ha and 5.1 tonnes/ha respectively for dryland and irrigated wheat, respectively. Inputs for dryland and irrigated wheat cultivation are obtained prmarily from farm budgets, the Department of Agriculture and Fisheries Wheat production guideline and the FAO. Emissions are calculated from fertilser and pesticide inputs.

This activity starts with soil cultivation after the harvest of the previous crop.

This activity ends after harvest of grains at the farm gate.
The dataset includes the inputs of seeds, mineral fertilisers, pesticides and all machine operations and corresponding machine infrastructure. Machine operations are: soil cultivation, sowing, fertilisation, irrigation, weed control, pest and pathogen control, and combine-harvesting. Direct field emissions are also included. The use of car, van or pick-up for servicing people, e.g. from farm to field, is not included in the activities.
category: A:Agriculture, forestry and fishing/01:Crop and animal production, hunting and related service activities/011:Growing of non-perennial crops/0111:Growing of cereals (except rice), leguminous crops and oil seeds

processDocumentation.timeDescription: The production volumes represent production figures for the 2016/2017 growing season reported in 2017 Abstract of Agricultural Statistics. References: DAFF (2017) Abstract of Agricultural Statistics 2017, Department of Agriculture, Forestry and Fisheries of South Africa, Available at: http://www.daff.gov.za/Daffweb3/Portals/0/Statistics%20and%20Economic%20Analysis/Statistical%20Information/Abstract%202017.pdf. (Accessed September 2017).
processDocumentation.geographyDescription: The inventory is modelled for the region of South Africa
processDocumentation.technologyDescription: The data are intended to reflect current equipment and processes in South Africa.
processDocumentation.samplingDescription:
Energy and material inputs, as well as land use and production (yield) are from commercial enterprise budgets (Combuds) for wheat farms in South Africa (three dryland and one irrigated), as well as a LEAP/FAO (2015) dataset on irrigated wheat in South Africa. The Department of Agriculture, Forestry and Fisheries's Wheat Production Guideline (DAFF 2016), Grain SA publications and academic publications  provided a further source of inputs, planting schedules etc. References are provided in the comment fields). A breakdown in the kind of fertilsers used is obtained from the FAO (2005). Wheat production volumes and areas are obtained from government agricultural statistics
DAFF (2017). References: FAO (2005) Fertiliser Use by Crop in South Africa, Food and Agriculture Organisation ofo the United Nations, Available at: ftp://ftp.fao.org/agl/agll/docs/fertusesouthafrica.pdf. (Accessed August 2017); FAO (2015) Online Database:  Global Database of GHG Emissions Related to Feed Crop, Food and Agriculture Organisation of the United Nations, Available at: http://www.fao.org/partnerships/leap/database/ghg-crops/en/. (Accessed September 2017); DAFF (2016) Production Guideline for Wheat,Department of Agriculture, Forestry and Fisheries of South Africa, Available at: http://www.daff.gov.za/Daffweb3/Portals/0/Brochures%20and%20Production%20guidelines/Wheat%20-%20Production%20Guideline.pdf (accessed September 2017); DAFF (2017) Abstract of Agricultural Statistics 2017, Department of Agriculture, Forestry and Fisheries of South Africa, Available at: http://www.daff.gov.za/Daffweb3/Portals/0/Statistics%20and%20Economic%20Analysis/Statistical%20Information/Abstract%202017.pdf. (Accessed September 2017).

exchanges.description: Modelled using the SALCA-P model as recommended by Nemecek and Schnetzer (2011). See supporting documentation for further details. Reference(s): Nemecek and Schnetzer (2011) Methods of Assessment of Direct Field Emissions for LCIs of Agricultural Production Systems, Life cycle inventories of Swiss and European agricultural production systems.

flow.name: Phosphate
flow.category: Elementary flows/Emission to water/surface water

exchanges.description: Centre pivot irrigation. Calculated from the blue water use for wheat production per province from the Water Footprint Network (in m3/tonne) (WFN, 2011) and the irrigated provincial tonnages according to the AgriCensus. This gives an average water use per irrigated tonne of wheat produced of 614 m3/tonne. In this dataset, 38% of wheat is grown under irrigation. References: WFN (2011) Product Water Footprint Statistics: Water footprints of crops and derived crop products (1996-2005), Water Footprint Network, Available at: http://waterfootprint.org/en/resources/water-footprint-statistics/. (Accessed September 2017); Stats SA (2007) Census of Commercial Agriculture, 2007: Financial and Production Statistics, Available at: http://www.nda.agric.za/docs/statsinfo/Censcoagric2007.pdf. (Accessed September 2017).

exchanges.description: The exchange has been updated from 'potassium chloride, as K2O' into 'potassium chloride' and therefore its amount has been scaled (multiplied) from 0.0002 kg by 1.5829 kg of 'potassium chloride' per kg of 'potassium chloride, as K2O'. Original comment of the exchange is: This figure represents K2O from KCl. Total amount of K as K2O determined from the calculated nitrogen application rates and the typical mineral ratio of nutrients N:P:K annually consumed by wheat in the region (FAO, 2005). K2O based fertilisers are all imported, with the bulk of imports being KCl. See details for disaggregation in supporting documentation. Reference(s): FAO (2005) Fertiliser Use by Crop in South Africa, Food and Agriculture Organisation ofo the United Nations, Available at: ftp://ftp.fao.org/agl/agll/docs/fertusesouthafrica.pdf. (Accessed August 2017).

exchanges.description: Modelled according to the 2006 IPCC Guidelines for National Greenhouse Gas Inventories. Default emission factor of 0.3 kg N input emitted as NO3 (kg NO3-N) applied to production under irrigation, which accounts for 38% of total production in South Africa. An emission factor of zero was assumed for dryland wheat production, as prescribed. See supporting documentation for further details.

exchanges.description: Total amount of active substance/s of fertilisers needed for the production of 'wheat grain' is calculated to be circa 1.49E-01 kg. Fertiliser/s used in this dataset is/are: 'ammonia, liquid', 'ammonium nitrate, as N', 'ammonium sulfate, as N', 'lime', 'nitrogen fertiliser, as N', 'phosphate fertiliser, as P2O5', 'potassium chloride, as K2O', 'potassium sulfate, as K2O', 'urea, as N'. The total amount of active substance/s is doubled in order to account for the packaging of the dilluted product of fertiliser/s that is/are applied. Therefore, 2.98E-01 kg of packaging for fertilisers is justified with this exchange.

exchanges.description: Emissions of heavy metals to soil and surface water estimated based on recommended method in Nemecek and Schnetzer (2011). Reference(s): Nemecek and Schnetzer (2011) Methods of Assessment of Direct Field Emissions for LCIs of Agricultural Production Systems, Life cycle inventories of Swiss and European agricultural production systems.

flow.name: Lead II
flow.category: Elementary flows/Emission to water/surface water

exchanges.description: Estimated using annual frequency of 1 and 100% mechanical operation. Based on field work process data for conventional irrigated wheat in South Africa, namely number of applications, and the % of the process which is performed mechanically versus manually (FAO, 2015). Using this data and the correlating ecoinvent datasets, the total diesel consumption [kg/ha] was determined, which correlated well with the total diesel consumption reported in the commercial enterprise budgets (combuds) for selected irrigated and dryland wheat farms in the North West and Western Cape Provinces of South Africa, respectively (GreenCape, 2015). Reference(s): FAO (2015) Online Database: Global Database of GHG Emissions Related to Feed Crop, Food and Agriculture Organisation of the United Nations, Available at: http://www.fao.org/partnerships/leap/database/ghg-crops/en/. (Accessed September 2017); GreenCape (2015) Regional Resource Flow Model: Grain Sector Report, Available at: https://www.greencape.co.za/assets/Bioeconomy/RRFM-Grain-Sector-Report-Mar-2015-Final-Website-2017.pdf. (Accessed September 2017).

exchanges.description: Total amount of active substance/s of pesticides needed for the production of wheat grain is calculated to be circa 3.27E-04 kg. Pesticide/s used in this dataset is/are: '[sulfonyl]urea-compound', 'captan', 'chemical, inorganic', 'glyphosate', 'magnesium sulfate', 'nitrile-compound', 'organophosphorus-compound, unspecified', 'pesticide, unspecified', 'phenoxy-compound'. The total amount of active substance/s is doubled in order to account for the packaging of the dilluted product of pesticide/s that is/are applied. Therefore, 6.53E-04 kg of packaging for pesticides is justified with this exchange.

flow.name: Phosphate
flow.category: Elementary flows/Emission to water/ground water

exchanges.description: Overall yield for 2016/2017 growing season of 3.8 tonnes/hectare equates to a land use per tonne of 0.26 hectares (DAFF, 2017). This overall land use is split into irrigated and non-irrigated land use using data from the 2007 AgriCensus, adjusted to account for increased yield between 2006 and 2016. Applied values are as follows: irrigated yield 5.1 tonnes/hectare, non-irrigated yield 3.0 tonnes/hectare, percentage irrigated 38%, and % non-irrigated 62%. Reference(s): DAFF (2017) Abstract of Agricultural Statistics 2017, Department of Agriculture, Forestry and Fisheries of South Africa, Available at: http://www.daff.gov.za/Daffweb3/Portals/0/Statistics%20and%20Economic%20Analysis/Statistical%20Information/Abstract%202017.pdf. (Accessed September 2017); Stats SA (2007) Census of Commercial Agriculture, 2007: Financial and Production Statistics, Available at: http://www.nda.agric.za/docs/statsinfo/Censcoagric2007.pdf. (Accessed September 2017).

exchanges.description: The exchange has been updated from 'urea, as N' into 'urea' and therefore its amount has been scaled (multiplied) from 0.004 kg by 2.1438 kg of 'urea' per kg of 'urea, as N'. Original comment of the exchange is: Based on average application rate of nitrogen [kg N/ha] and a breakdown of the mineral nutrient by fertiliser type based on that of a conventional irrigated wheat operation (FAO, 2015). A weighted average was estimated based the an average application rate of 28kg N/ha for dryland wheat and 97kg N/ha for irrigated wheat extracted from commercial enterprise budgets (Combuds) for selected farms in the Western Cape region (GreenCape, 2015). See details for disaggregation in supporting documentation. Reference(s): FAO (2005) Fertiliser Use by Crop in South Africa, Food and Agriculture Organisation ofo the United Nations, Available at: ftp://ftp.fao.org/agl/agll/docs/fertusesouthafrica.pdf. (Accessed August 2017); FAO (2015) Online Database:  Global Database of GHG Emissions Related to Feed Crop, Food and Agriculture Organisation of the United Nations, Available at: http://www.fao.org/partnerships/leap/database/ghg-crops/en/. (Accessed September 2017); Stats SA (2007) Census of Commercial Agriculture, 2007: Financial and Production Statistics, Available at: http://www.nda.agric.za/docs/statsinfo/Censcoagric2007.pdf. (Accessed September 2017).

exchanges.description: Estimate is a weighted average of lime consumption [kg/tonne] for irrigated and dryland wheat, and the estimated breakdown of irrigated versus dryland wheat production. Lime consumption figures calculated based on the total fertiliser and lime consumption [t/ha] of selected irrigated and dryland wheat farms reported in Western Cape commercial enterprise budgets (Combuds) (GreenCape, 2015), the total nutrient consumption from synthetic fertilisers irrigated and dryland wheat (GreenCape, 2015, FAO, 2005) and an assumed average concentration of the synthetic fertilisers of 30%. Reference(s): FAO (2005) Fertiliser Use by Crop in South Africa, Food and Agriculture Organisation ofo the United Nations, Available at: ftp://ftp.fao.org/agl/agll/docs/fertusesouthafrica.pdf. (Accessed August 2017); GreenCape (2015) Regional Resource Flow Model: Grain Sector Report, Available at: https://www.greencape.co.za/assets/Bioeconomy/RRFM-Grain-Sector-Report-Mar-2015-Final-Website-2017.pdf. (Accessed September 2017).

exchanges.description: This figure represents the mass of the active ingredient for the pesticide Hoelon, methyl 2-[4-(2,4-dichlorophenoxy) phenoxy]propanoate. Average application rates for pesticides were extracted from commercial enterprise budgets (combuds) for selected dryland wheat farms (GreenCape, 2015). The pesticide application rates for dryland wheat were assumed to be representative for the average South African wheat farm. Reference(s): GreenCape (2015) Regional Resource Flow Model: Grain Sector Report, Available at: https://www.greencape.co.za/assets/Bioeconomy/RRFM-Grain-Sector-Report-Mar-2015-Final-Website-2017.pdf. (Accessed September 2017).

exchanges.description: Land occupation per growing season is taken to be 12 months, because where crop rotation is practiced, it is on an annual basis (short-term rotation) or every 5 years (long-term rotation) (Grain SA, 2015). Overall yield for 2016/2017 growing season of 3.8 tonnes/hectare equates to a land use per tonne of 0.26 hectares (DAFF, 2017). This overall land use is split into irrigated and non-irrigated land use using data from the 2007 AgriCensus, adjusted to account for increased yield between 2006 and 2016. Applied values are as follows: irrigated yield 5.1 tonnes/hectare, non-irrigated yield 3.0 tonnes/hectare, percentage irrigated 38%, and % non-irrigated 62%. Reference(s): DAFF (2017) Abstract of Agricultural Statistics 2017, Department of Agriculture, Forestry and Fisheries of South Africa, Available at: http://www.daff.gov.za/Daffweb3/Portals/0/Statistics%20and%20Economic%20Analysis/Statistical%20Information/Abstract%202017.pdf. (Accessed September 2017); Stats SA (2007) Census of Commercial Agriculture, 2007: Financial and Production Statistics, Available at: http://www.nda.agric.za/docs/statsinfo/Censcoagric2007.pdf. flow.name: Carbon dioxide, in air
flow.category: Elementary flows/Resource/in air

exchanges.description: This figure represents P2O5 from MAP (11% N, 52% P2O5), DAP (18% N, 46% P2O5), and SSP. Total amount of P as P2O5 determined from the calculated nitrogen application rates and the typical mineral ratio of nutrients N:P:K annually consumed by wheat in the region (FAO, 2005). MAP and DAP as P2O5 calculated based on N application rates (MAP, DAP). SSP application was assumed to make up the remainder. See details for disaggregation in supporting documentation. Reference(s): FAO (2005) Fertiliser Use by Crop in South Africa, Food and Agriculture Organisation ofo the United Nations, Available at: ftp://ftp.fao.org/agl/agll/docs/fertusesouthafrica.pdf. (Accessed August 2017).

exchanges.description: The exchange has been updated from 'potassium sulfate, as K2O' into 'potassium sulfate' and therefore its amount has been scaled (multiplied) from 0.0014 kg by 1.85 kg of 'potassium sulfate' per kg of 'potassium sulfate, as K2O'. Original comment of the exchange is: This figure represents K2O from potassium sulphate. Total amount of K as K2O determined from the calculated nitrogen application rates and the typical mineral ratio of nutrients N:P:K annually consumed by wheat in the region (FAO, 2005). K2O based fertilisers are all imported, with the bulk of imports being KCl. See details for disaggregation in supporting documentation. Reference(s): FAO (2005) Fertiliser Use by Crop in South Africa, Food and Agriculture Organisation ofo the United Nations, Available at: ftp://ftp.fao.org/agl/agll/docs/fertusesouthafrica.pdf. (Accessed August 2017).

flow.name: Ammonia
flow.category: Elementary flows/Emission to air/low population density

exchanges.description: Estimated using annual frequency of 1 and 100% mechanical operation. Based on field work process data for conventional irrigated wheat in South Africa, namely number of applications, and the % of the process which is performed mechanically versus manually (FAO, 2015). Using this data and the correlating ecoinvent datasets, the total diesel consumption [kg/ha] was determined, which correlated well with the total diesel consumption reported in the commercial enterprise budgets (combuds) for selected irrigated and dryland wheat farms in the North West and Western Cape Provinces of South Africa, respectively (GreenCape, 2015). Reference(s): FAO (2015) Online Database: Global Database of GHG Emissions Related to Feed Crop, Food and Agriculture Organisation of the United Nations, Available at: http://www.fao.org/partnerships/leap/database/ghg-crops/en/. (Accessed September 2017); GreenCape (2015) Regional Resource Flow Model: Grain Sector Report, Available at: https://www.greencape.co.za/assets/Bioeconomy/RRFM-Grain-Sector-Report-Mar-2015-Final-Website-2017.pdf. (Accessed September 2017).

exchanges.description: Overall yield for 2016/2017 growing season of 3.8 tonnes/hectare equates to a land use per tonne of 0.26 hectares (DAFF, 2017). This overall land use is split into irrigated and non-irrigated land use using data from the 2007 AgriCensus, adjusted to account for increased yield between 2006 and 2016. Applied values are as follows: irrigated yield 5.1 tonnes/hectare, non-irrigated yield 3.0 tonnes/hectare, percentage irrigated 38%, and % non-irrigated 62%. Reference(s): DAFF (2017) Abstract of Agricultural Statistics 2017, Department of Agriculture, Forestry and Fisheries of South Africa, Available at: http://www.daff.gov.za/Daffweb3/Portals/0/Statistics%20and%20Economic%20Analysis/Statistical%20Information/Abstract%202017.pdf. (Accessed September 2017); Stats SA (2007) Census of Commercial Agriculture, 2007: Financial and Production Statistics, Available at: http://www.nda.agric.za/docs/statsinfo/Censcoagric2007.pdf. (Accessed September 2017).

exchanges.description: This figure represents the mass of the active ingredient for the pesticide Captan, N-trichtoromethylthio~cyclohexene-1,2-dicarboximide (phthalimide class of fungicides). Average application rates for pesticides were extracted from commercial enterprise budgets (combuds) for selected dryland wheat farms (GreenCape, 2015). The pesticide application rates for dryland wheat were assumed to be representative for the average South African wheat farm. Reference(s): GreenCape (2015) Regional Resource Flow Model: Grain Sector Report, Available at: https://www.greencape.co.za/assets/Bioeconomy/RRFM-Grain-Sector-Report-Mar-2015-Final-Website-2017.pdf. exchanges.description: The exchange has been updated from 'ammonium nitrate, as N' into 'ammonium nitrate' and therefore its amount has been scaled (multiplied) from 0.0012 kg by 2.8573 kg of 'ammonium nitrate' per kg of 'ammonium nitrate, as N'. Original comment of the exchange is: Based on average application rate of nitrogen [kg N/ha] and a breakdown of the mineral nutrient by fertiliser type based on that of a conventional irrigated wheat operation (FAO, 2015). A weighted average was estimated based the an average application rate of 28kg N/ha for dryland wheat and 97kg N/ha for irrigated wheat extracted from commercial enterprise budgets (Combuds) for selected farms in the Western Cape region (GreenCape, 2015). See details for disaggregation in supporting documentation. Reference(s): FAO (2005) Fertiliser Use by Crop in South Africa, Food and Agriculture Organisation ofo the United Nations, Available at: ftp://ftp.fao.org/agl/agll/docs/fertusesouthafrica.pdf. (Accessed August 2017); FAO (2015) Online Database:  Global Database of GHG Emissions Related to Feed Crop, Food and Agriculture Organisation of the United Nations, Available at: http://www.fao.org/partnerships/leap/database/ghg-crops/en/. flow.name: Phosphorus
flow.category: Elementary flows/Emission to water/surface water

exchanges.description: Land occupation per growing season is taken to be 12 months, because where crop rotation is practiced, it is on an annual basis (short-term rotation) or every 5 years (long-term rotation) (Grain SA, 2015). Where crop rotation is not practiced, soil preparation is recommended to begin two weeks after harvesting (DAFF, 2016). Overall yield for 2016/2017 growing season of 3.8 tonnes/hectare equates to a land use per tonne of 0.26 hectares (DAFF, 2017). This overall land use is split into irrigated and non-irrigated land use using data from the 2007 AgriCensus, adjusted to account for increased yield between 2006 and 2016. Applied values are as follows: irrigated yield 5.1 tonnes/hectare, non-irrigated yield 3.0 tonnes/hectare, percentage irrigated 38%, and % non-irrigated 62%. Reference(s): DAFF (2017) Abstract of Agricultural Statistics 2017, Department of Agriculture, Forestry and Fisheries of South Africa, Available at: http://www.daff.gov.za/Daffweb3/Portals/0/Statistics%20and%20Economic%20Analysis/Statistical%20Information/Abstract%202017.pdf. (Accessed September 2017); Stats SA (2007) Census of Commercial Agriculture, 2007: Financial and Production Statistics, Available at: http://www.nda.agric.za/docs/statsinfo/Censcoagric2007.pdf. (Accessed September 2017); Grain SA (2015) Improve Your Wheat Yield with Crop Rotation, Available at: http://www.grainsa.co.za/improve-your-wheat-yield-with-crop-rotation. (Accessed September 2017).; DAFF (2016) Production Guideline for Wheat. Available at: http://www.daff.gov.za/Daffweb3/Portals/0/Brochures%20and%20Production%20guidelines/Wheat%20-%20Production%20Guideline.pdf (Accessed September 2017).
